items.description: River Cole and Dorcan Brook
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the River Cole and Dorcan Brook as a result of heavy rainfall today. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected this afternoon (05/08/2023), especially in the Lower Stratton area. Further heavy showers are forecast this afternoon which have the potential to be heavy at times. The rain should clear this evening leaving overnight mainly dry. River levels are forecast to fall overnight, but may be responsive to further heavy showers. Our incident response staff are in the area clearing trash screens. Refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated this evening, 05/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middlesbrough Becks
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels are now falling steadily. The heaviest of the rainfall is now cleared. 
There is no longer a threat of flooding, although standing water and debris may still remain. We may see further rainfall over the next few days and this Flood Alert will be re-issued if needed.
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are clearing debris from trash screens.

items.description: River Seven catchment
items.message: River levels are rising on the River Seven due to heavy rainfall this morning. Flooding is expected today, Saturday 05/08/2023. Areas most at risk include land around the River Seven and it's tributaries including Northdale Beck, Hartoft Beck, Ings Beck, Lastingham Beck, Sutherland Beck, Cropton Beck, Catter Beck, Sinnington and to the East of Normanby. Further rainfall is forecast during Saturday which is expected to keep levels high during the day and overnight. There is less rain forecast from Sunday 06/08/2023 onwards, so flood risk is expected to reduce. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 21:00 Saturday 05/08/2023 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Lee tributaries

floodArea.county: Barnet, Enfield, Essex, Greater London, Haringey, Hertfordshire, Redbridge, Waltham Forest
floodArea.riverOrSea: Ching Brook, Cobbins Brook, Nazeing Brook, Pymmes Brook, Salmons Brook, Turkey Brook, Small River Lee, Rags Brook, Trinity Marsh Ditch

items.message:
We have issued a Flood Alert. Storm Antoni is forecast to bring thunderstorms affecting London from midday on Saturday 5 August. It is currently unclear which areas will experience the heaviest rain.

If the heaviest rain affects the Waltham Forest, Waltham Abbey, Waltham Cross, Barnet, Nazeing, Enfield, Chingford, Edmonton, Cheshunt or Tottenham areas, there is the possibility that rivers could overtop their banks. Flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside gardens is possible from midday on Saturday. Flooding from surface water could also occur.

We expect river levels to respond by rising quickly in areas receiving the heaviest rain. We recommend you stay aware of local weather conditions and water levels. Consider putting your flood plan into action.

We expect the band of rain to leave the area on Saturday evening, scattered showers are forecast for Sunday. We are constantly monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages.

We will update this message on Saturday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Porlock Weir
items.message:
This flood alert has been issued due to high spring tides combined with high winds. Forecast high water is 22:45 on 05/08/23 with a level of 6.23 mAOD and a Force 6 North Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. 

Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at this time, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.

This set of spring tides has now passed its peak and coastal conditions are expected to improve from Sunday.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.
  
This message will be updated by 12:00 on Sunday, 06/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.63mAOD at 18:30 on 05/08/23 and 4.67mAOD at 07:00 on 06/08/23.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 35 cubic metres per second and is rising. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next 3 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:30 on 06/08/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coastal Streams in Redcar and Cleveland
items.message:
River levels on the Loftus and Skinningrove Becks have fallen following the clearance of heavy rain. Properties have been flooded in Loftus. 

Further showers are possible overnight tonight (Saturday 05/08/2023). However these will not be as heavy or persistent as earlier today and no further flooding impacts are expected.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. We will continue to work with emergency services and local authorities. Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. If you have been evacuated only return to your property once the emergency services have advised that it is safe to do so.

items.description: Thorney Island to Bracklesham
items.message: Sunday’s early morning tide at 03:00 on 06/08/2023 is forecast to be approximately 35 cm lower than Saturday afternoon’s. Through Sunday the wind speed and wave heights will fall. Tides are now reducing towards a set of neaps. No more than minimal flood impacts are currently expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Sunday’s early morning tide at 03:15 on 06/08/2023 is forecast to be approximately 35 cm lower than Saturday afternoon’s. Through Sunday the wind speed and wave heights will fall. Tides are now reducing towards a set of neaps. No more than minimal flood impacts are currently expected. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: Strong winds and spring tides are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast Sunday morning 06/08/2023. Areas most at risk include the Southfield farm coast and Spurn Road. Flooding is possible between 07:30 and 12:00 on Sunday morning. After this tide‚ the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 14:00 on 06/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message:
A combination of strong winds  during spring tides, means that higher tides are expected  between 8:15am and 12:15pm tomorrow, Sunday 6th August. Flooding to the promenade is possible at these times, with large waves and sea spray overtopping likely.  Areas most at risk are around Hunstanton seafront. 

Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority which will make access difficult.

The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of  4.54mAODN at 10:15am, on Sunday 6th August, which is 0.22m above tide tables, wind force 6, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  The following tide on Sunday 6th August at 11:00pm is currently forecast to be below the Alert threshold.

Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences. We will update this message by 1pm tomorrow or earlier if conditions change.

items.description: Coast from Heacham to north of King's Lynn in Norfolk
items.message:
A combination of strong winds during spring tides, means that higher tides are expected  between 8:15am and 12:15pm tomorrow, Sunday 6th August. Flooding to the promenade is possible at these times, with large waves and sea spray overtopping likely. Areas most at risk are Heacham, Snettisham, Ingoldisthorpe, Dersingham and Wolferton. 

The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of  4.54 mAODN at 10:15am, on Sunday 6th August, which is 0.22m above tide tables, wind force 6, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  The following tide on Sunday 6th August at 23:00pm is currently forecast to be below the Alert threshold.

Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. Our workforce are out checking flood defences. We will update this message by 1pm tomorrow or earlier, if conditions change.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths may occur early tomorrow morning, Sunday 6th August, between 3:30am and 5:30am. This is due to an unseasonal low pressure system causing a small tidal surge. Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low lying land between the fort and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.48mAODN at 4:30am on Sunday 6th August, which is 0.28m above tide tables, wind force 6, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). The following tide at 4:45pm on Sunday 6th August is not expected reach the Flood Alert threshold. You are advised to stay away from at risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Sunday 6th August.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: Tide levels are now below the flood risk threshold. The forecast is for no further flood risk from high tides today. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely and re-issue a flood alert if necessary.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from Old Hunstanton, to and including Cley
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths may occur tomorrow morning, Sunday 6th August, between 9:30am and 11:30am. This is due to an unseasonal low pressure system causing a small tidal surge. We expect to see water on roads and paths to beaches and on the quays in Brancaster, Burnham Overy, Holkham, Wells and Blakeney. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.60mAODN at 10:30am on Sunday 6th August, which is 0.31m above tide tables, wind force 6, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). The following tide at 11:15pm on Sunday 6th August is not expected to reach the Flood Alert threshold. You are advised to stay away from at risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 12:30pm tomorrow, Sunday 6th August.

items.description: The north Norfolk coast from East Cley to Kelling Hard, including Salthouse
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths may occur tomorrow morning, Sunday 6th August, between 9:30am and 11:30am. This is due to an unseasonal low pressure system causing a small tidal surge. We may see water on Beach Road at Cley, and Beach Road at Salthouse, and footpaths in the marshes may also become inaccessible.  The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.60mAODN at 10:30am on Sunday 6th August, which is 0.31m above tide tables, wind force 6, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). The following tide at 11:15pm on Sunday 6th August is not expected to reach the Flood Alert threshold. You are advised to stay away from at risk areas, and take care next to the coast. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 12:30pm tomorrow, Sunday 6th August.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: Strong winds and spring tides are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast Sunday morning 06/08/2023. Areas most at risk include Kilnsea Village. Flooding is possible between 07:30 and 12:00 on Sunday morning. After this tide‚ the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 14:00 on 06/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: River levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent due to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding remains possible today, Saturday 05/08/2023. Areas most at risk include low lying land, roads and footpaths in the Upper Derwent around Low Marishes and smaller tributaries in the Scarborough area around the Sea Cut, Scalby and Cloughton. Further rainfall is forecast during Saturday and overnight into Sunday morning 06/08/2023 which is expected to keep levels high. There is less rain forecast from Sunday onwards, so flood risk is expected to reduce. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00 on Sunday morning 06/08/2023 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
The flood forecast has changed. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides.

The weather is forecast to be more settled and no further impacts are expected.

items.description: Wye Estuary in Gloucestershire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. Incoming high tide levels are now forecast to be below the Flood Alert threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.   
Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.description: Mersey Estuary at Warrington
items.message:
The high tide has now passed.

No further high tides are expected to reach Flood Alert levels in this cycle.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and issue further alerts if necessary.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
Tide levels are now decreasing. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides and no further impacts are expected. 
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the sea has now reduced, however, large waves and gale force winds are forecast, so take care near coastal paths and promenades.

items.description: Silk Stream and the Deans, Edgware, Dollis, Mutton and Wealdstone Brooks
items.message:
We have issued a Flood Alert. Storm Antoni is forecast to bring thunderstorms affecting London from midday on Saturday 5 August. It is currently unclear which areas will see the heaviest rain.

If the heaviest rain affects the Hendon, Wembley, Harrow, Wealdstone, Edgware or Stanmore areas there is the possibility that rivers could overtop their banks. Flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside gardens is possible from midday on Saturday. Flooding from surface water may also occur.

We expect river levels to rise quickly in areas receiving the heaviest rain. We recommend you stay aware of local weather conditions and water levels. Consider putting your flood plan into action.

We expect the band of rain to leave the area on Saturday evening. We are constantly monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages.

We are continuing to deploy pumps, people and equipment, and liaising with emergency services and local authorities in the Tokyngton area on the Wembley Brook.

We will update this message on Saturday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Severn Estuary at Severn Beach
items.message:
The flood forecast has changed. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area. The risk of flooding from Storm Antoni has now reduced.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Lower River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message: River levels remain high on the lower River Derwent due to heavy rainfall on Saturday 05/08/2023. Areas most at risk of flooding this evening and overnight include local roads and low-lying land around Elvington and Thornton Beck. Further rainfall is forecast during Saturday and overnight into Sunday morning 06/08/2023 which is expected to keep levels high. Levels are expected to remain high throughout the weekend. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 on Sunday morning 06/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Level of the Fens in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk
items.message: River levels are forecast to rise in response to the current weather conditions.  Areas most at risk are around Middle Level, including Pondersbridge, Ramsey St Mary's, Benwick and Welney.   Further heavy rainfall is expected over the 12 hours which will keep river levels high and could also lead to some surface water problems. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, 06/08/23, or if the situation changes.
